<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of fill_v1_v2_form:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
fill_v1_v2_form (const void *cls,
                 const char *mime,
                 struct Session *session,
                 struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  char *reply;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  size_t slen;
  (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  slen = strlen (SECOND_PAGE) + strlen (session->value_1)
         + strlen (session->value_2);
  reply = malloc (slen + 1);
  if (NULL == reply)
    return MHD_NO;
  snprintf (reply,
            slen + 1,
            SECOND_PAGE,
            session->value_1,
            session->value_2);
  /* return static form */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen,
                                                        (void *) reply,
                                                        &free);
  if (NULL == response)
  {
    free (reply);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  add_session_cookie (session, response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_OK,
                            response);
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  reply = malloc (slen + 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The malloc call itself does not invoke any <string.h> functions and allocates slen+1 bytes where slen was computed from strlen(SECOND_PAGE) + strlen(session->value_1) + strlen(session->value_2). That allocation provides space for the summed character lengths plus the terminating NUL. Given a SECOND_PAGE that uses %s placeholders, this sizing is conservative (strlen counts the "%s" characters too, so the allocation is >= the formatted output length). A real violation of Rule 21.17 could occur elsewhere if session->value_1 or session->value_2 are not properly NUL-terminated (strlen would then read out-of-bounds) or if other string.h functions are later used with incorrectly sized buffers—but the single fragment reply = malloc (slen + 1); does not itself violate Rule 21.17.
